div.head: General observations
div.p: Sols RT+Stock: These spectra demonstrate that Au(III) complexes quite strongly with Br. With a of Br:Cl=1, the AuBr 4 -species predominates. We collected a systematic series of spectra at varying Cl:Br ratio, enabling comparison with recent UV-Vis data used to derive thermodynamic properties for Au(III)-chloride-bromide complexes.

Sol 1: XANES, k and R-space similar for all temperatures. This is consistent with the result of Pokrovski et al. (2009), that AuS 2 -is the dominant Au-species in near-neutral (4-5≤pH≤8-9) over a wide range of TPx. The spectra are similar to the Au-S spectra in basic solutions from Pokrovski et al. (2009), and can be fitted with AuS 2 -. Sol2: [AuBr 4 ] -at 35 o C; looses pre-edge upon heating and spectra become increasingly metallic (3 rd spectrum at 170 o C closely resembles metallic Au), precipitates evident in solution. Sol3,4,16: Very little Au in solution at all temperatures, spectra resemble metallic-like Au. Sol 5: Competition between Br and S. Spectra at all temperatures (222-436 o C) look similar. These experimental spectra are all identical to Sol1 and not at all like Sol8 (114 o C); this implies that the bonding is AuS 2 -, with no Br!! Sol 6: Competition between Br and Cl. High background due to As, very little Au in solution. Spectra (114 o C) almost identical to Sol8 (114 o C, AuBr 2 -) and quite different to Sol11 (114 o C, AuCl 2 -). At higher temperaures there are particles in solution and the pre-edge decreased, impling Au is precipitating. This implies that at 114 o C Au(I) preferentially binds with Br rather than Cl. Sol 7: High background due to As; very little Au in solution. Spectra looked similar for all temperatures; spectra identical to Sol8 (114 o C). Sol 8: [AuBr 4 ] -at 35 o C; spectra resemble metallic-Au at 420 o C (with precipitates in solution). At intermediate temperatures (114-222 o C), spectra are very similar and most closely resemble that of the AuCl 2 -standard (Reith, pers comm) -but the white line is lower. This lower white line is due to Br being the ligand, rather than Cl (see RT spectra, the more Br, the lower the white line even though total halide concentration was constant); Sol8 can be fitted as AuBr 2 -. Sol 9: Competition between Br and Cl. Spectra resemble Sol11 (114 o C, AuCl 2 -) at all temperatures. Interestingly, in this solution Au seems to be predominantly bonded to Cl; apparently the Br:Cl ratio is important (Br:Cl=1:1, preferentially bonded to Br, Sol6.) Sol 10: Competition between Br and Cl. [AuBr 4 ] -at 35 o C; first 114 o C spectrum is ~halfway between Sol8 (114 o C, AuBr 2 -) and Sol11 (114 o C, AuCl 2 ), the fourth spectrum (114 o C) is more similar to Sol8 (114 o C), but still has some Cl component. At 168 o C spectra are almost identical to Sol8 (114 o C). It is interesting that Sol9 and Sol10 seem so different, why is this? Sol 11: [AuCl 4 ] -at 35 o C (spectrum is a bit different to [AuBr 4 ] -). White line decreases on heating, becoming AuCl 2 -. Sol 12: Competition between Br and Cl. Interestingly the spectrum at 35 o C closely resembles [AuBr 4 ] -(standard solution rather than Sol8 …); with heating the white line decreases, at 222 o C the spectrum is more similar to Sol8 (114 o C, AuBr 2 -) than to Sol11 (114 o C, AuCl 2 ). Sol 13: Spectra identical for all measured temperatures, and are identical to Sol1 (AuS 2 -). Sol 14: Competition between Br and Cl. At 114 o C the spectrum is more similar to Sol8 (114 o C, AuBr 2 -) than to Sol11 (114 o C, AuCl 2 ). Experimental: Data were collected at the Au L 3 -edge (11.919 keV) at the BM-30B (FAME) beam line, using the high T-P cell developed by the CNRS. The energy was calibrated with metallic Au, such that the maximum of the first derivative was at 11.919 keV.
